{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3538090,"name":"jls667","username":"jls667","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/c77e96/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-24T16:11:19.846Z","cooked":"

Should tuning the swerve pid coefficients be necessary? I am able to drive in teleop fine. It is autonomous that is not really working. When I put the robot on blocks, the robot seems to generally go in the right direction, but the wheels are still rotating when the drive wheels are moving. Is it even possible to tune pid coefficients when using yagsl?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-24T16:27:51.198Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":35,"reads":109,"readers_count":108,"score":196.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":492964,"topic_slug":"yagsl-swerve-pid-coefficients","display_username":"jls667","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22346,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/yagsl-swerve-pid-coefficients/492964/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3538123,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-24T16:33:40.553Z","cooked":"

You can’t test tuning on blocks; it has to be under a similar loading condition to actual operation.

If you want to fine-tune things, YAGSL is probably not the right choice. It’s not that hard to plumb up the WPILib classes yourself (there’s even an example project!).

What example project are you referencing? I only put the robot on blocks to see if my autonomous was doing anything remotely recognizable. My floor space is limited, especially for a possibly erratic robot.

jls667:

What example project are you referencing?

github.com

allwpilib/wpilibjExamples/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/examples/swervebot...

Official Repository of WPILibJ and WPILibC. Contribute to wpilibsuite/allwpilib development by creating an account on GitHub.

jls667:

I only put the robot on blocks to see if my autonomous was doing anything remotely recognizable. My floor space is limited, especially for a possibly erratic robot.

Loops that work under loading may be completely erratic when unloaded. If you don’t have space to run a routine it will be very hard to tune a routine.

I am not that good with programming swerve, that is why I chose YAGSL. It just seems like the swerve modules could rotate faster. I am using the suggested starting values of “P=50” and “D=.32” for Kraken X60 motors and MK4n modules. What have other people found with the same hardware?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-02-24T17:04:50.757Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":67,"readers_count":66,"score":18.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492964,"topic_slug":"yagsl-swerve-pid-coefficients","display_username":"jls667","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22346,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/yagsl-swerve-pid-coefficients/492964/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3538159,"name":"Prince","username":"Prince","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/ba9def/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-24T17:10:55.742Z","cooked":"

IMG_4768636×1015 104 KB

We have x60 for drive and angle. And we us mk4n’s .Here is our pid values. But I would highly suggest that you run sys id which is implemented into yagsl already to find you pid values. Use the test velocity values for your drive values and position for angle values. Also use the replace feedforward method in swerve subsystem to add in the extra feedback values from sysid
